 Describes if the image is big- or little- endian.

 The version of the ELF specification the image adheres to.

 Type of OS the image can be run on.

00311  /* Go through the linked list of executable images and verify that they
00312     are correct. At the same time build the executable_table. */
00313  {
00314   const struct executable_image* image;
00315 
00316   for (image=ELF_images_start; 0!=image; image=image->next)
00317   {
00318    unsigned long      image_size;
00319 
00320    /* First calculate the size of the image. */
00321    if (0 != image->next)
00322    {
00323     image_size = ((char *) (image->next)) - ((char *) image) -1;
00324    }
00325    else
00326    {
00327     image_size = ((char *) ELF_images_end) - ((char *) image) - 1;
00328    }
00329 
00330    /* Check that the image is an ELF image and that it is of the
00331       right type. */
00332    if (
00333        /* EI_MAG0 - EI_MAG3 have to be 0x7f 'E' 'L' 'F'. */
00334        (image->elf_image.e_ident[EI_MAG0] != 0x7f) ||
00335        (image->elf_image.e_ident[EI_MAG1] != 'E') ||
00336        (image->elf_image.e_ident[EI_MAG2] != 'L') ||
00337        (image->elf_image.e_ident[EI_MAG3] != 'F') ||
00338        /* Check that the image is a 64-bit image. */
00339        (image->elf_image.e_ident[EI_CLASS] != 2) ||
00340        /* Check that the image is a little endian image. */
00341        (image->elf_image.e_ident[EI_DATA] != 1) ||
00342        /* And that the version of the image format is correct. */
00343        (image->elf_image.e_ident[EI_VERSION] != 1) ||
00344        /* NB: We do not check the ABI or ABI version. We really should
00345           but currently those fields are not set properly by the build
00346           tools. They are both set to zero which means: System V ABI,
00347           third edition. However, the ABI used is clearly not System V :-) */
00348 
00349        /* Check that the image is executable. */
00350        (image->elf_image.e_type != 2) ||
00351        /* Check that the image is executable on AMD64. */
00352        (image->elf_image.e_machine != 0x3e) ||
00353        /* Check that the object format is corrent. */
00354        (image->elf_image.e_version != 1) ||
00355        /* Check that the processor dependent flags are all reset. */
00356        (image->elf_image.e_flags != 0) ||
00357        /* Check that the length of t   he header is what we expect. */
00358        (image->elf_image.e_ehsize != sizeof(struct Elf64_Ehdr)) ||
00359        /* Check that the size of the program header table entry is what
00360           we expect. */
00361        (image->elf_image.e_phentsize != sizeof(struct Elf64_Phdr)) ||
00362        /* Check that the number of entries is reasonable. */
00363        (image->elf_image.e_phnum < 0) ||
00364        (image->elf_image.e_phnum > 8) ||
00365        /* Check that the entry point is within the image. */
00366        (image->elf_image.e_entry < 0) ||
00367        (image->elf_image.e_entry >= image_size) ||
00368        /* Finally, check that the program header table is within the image. */
00369        (image->elf_image.e_phoff > image_size) ||
00370        ((image->elf_image.e_phoff +
00371          image->elf_image.e_phnum * sizeof(struct Elf64_Phdr)) > image_size )
00372       )
00373 
00374    {
00375     /* There is something wrong with the image. */
00376     while (1)
00377     {
00378      kprints("Kernel panic! Corrupt executable image.\n");
00379     }
00380     continue;
00381    }
00382 
00383    /* Now check the program header table. */
00384    {
00385     int                program_header_index;
00386     struct Elf64_Phdr* program_header = ((struct Elf64_Phdr*)
00387                                          (((char*) &(image->elf_image)) +
00388                                           image->elf_image.e_phoff));
00389     unsigned long      memory_footprint_size = 0;
00390 
00391     for (program_header_index = 0;
00392          program_header_index < image->elf_image.e_phnum;
00393          program_header_index++)
00394     {
00395      /* First sanity check the entry. */
00396      if (
00397          /* Check that the segment is a type we can handle. */
00398          (program_header[program_header_index].p_type < 0) ||
00399          (!((program_header[program_header_index].p_type == PT_NULL) ||
00400             (program_header[program_header_index].p_type == PT_LOAD) ||
00401             (program_header[program_header_index].p_type == PT_PHDR))) ||
00402          /* Look more carefully into loadable segments. */
00403          ((program_header[program_header_index].p_type == PT_LOAD) &&
00404            /* Check if any flags that we can not handle is set. */
00405           (((program_header[program_header_index].p_flags & ~7) != 0) ||
00406            /* Check if sizes and offsets look sane. */
00407            (program_header[program_header_index].p_offset < 0) ||
00408            (program_header[program_header_index].p_vaddr < 0) ||
00409            (program_header[program_header_index].p_filesz < 0) ||
00410            (program_header[program_header_index].p_memsz < 0) ||
00411           /* Check if the segment has an odd size. We require the
00412              segment size to be an even multiple of 8. */
00413            (0 != (program_header[program_header_index].p_memsz&7)) ||
00414            (0 != (program_header[program_header_index].p_filesz&7)) ||
00415            /* Check if the segment goes beyond the image. */
00416            ((program_header[program_header_index].p_offset +
00417              program_header[program_header_index].p_filesz) > image_size)))
00418         )
00419      {
00420       while (1)
00421       {
00422        kprints("Kernel panic! Corrupt segment.\n");
00423       }
00424      }
00425 
00426      /* Check that all PT_LOAD segments are contiguous starting from
00427         address 0. Also, calculate the memory footprint of the image. */
00428      if (program_header[program_header_index].p_type == PT_LOAD)
00429      {
00430       if (program_header[program_header_index].p_vaddr !=
00431           memory_footprint_size)
00432       {
00433        while (1)
00434        {
00435         kprints("Kernel panic! Executable image has illegal memory layout.\n");
00436        }
00437       }
00438 
00439       memory_footprint_size += program_header[program_header_index].p_memsz;
00440      }
00441     }
00442 
00443     executable_table[executable_table_size].memory_footprint_size =
00444      memory_footprint_size;
00445    }
00446 
00447    executable_table[executable_table_size].elf_image = &(image->elf_image);
00448    executable_table_size += 1;
00449 
00450    kprints("Found an executable image.\n");
00451 
00452    if (executable_table_size >= MAX_NUMBER_OF_PROCESSES)
00453    {
00454     while (1)
00455     {
00456      kprints("Kernel panic! Too many executable images found.\n");
00457     }
00458    }
00459   }
00460  }
00461 
00462  /* Check that actually some executable files are found. Also check that the
00463     thread structure is of the right size. The assembly code will break if it
00464     is not. Finally, initialize memory protection. You will implement memory
00465     protection in task A4. */
00466 
00467  if ((0 >= executable_table_size) ||
00468      (1024 != sizeof(union thread)))
00469  {
00470   while (1)
00471   {
00472    kprints("Kernel panic! Can not boot.\n");
00473   }
00474  }
00475 
00476  initialize_memory_protection();
00477  initialize_ports();
00478  initialize_thread_synchronization();
00479 
00480  /* All sub-systems are now initialized. Kernel areas can now get the right
00481     memory protection. */
00482 
00483  {
00484   /* Use the kernel's ELF header. */
00485   struct Elf32_Phdr* program_header = ((struct Elf32_Phdr*)
00486                                        (((char*) (0x00100000)) +
00487                                         ((struct Elf32_Ehdr*)0x00100000)->
00488                                           e_phoff));
00489 
00490   /* Traverse the program header. */
00491   short              number_of_program_header_entries =
00492                       ((struct Elf32_Ehdr*)0x00100000)->e_phnum;
00493   int                i;
00494   for(i=0; i<number_of_program_header_entries; i++)
00495   {
00496    if (PT_LOAD == program_header[i].p_type)
00497    {
00498     /* Set protection on each segment. */
00499 
00500     update_memory_protection(kernel_page_table_root,
00501                              program_header[i].p_vaddr,
00502                              program_header[i].p_memsz,
00503                              (program_header[i].p_flags&7) | PF_KERNEL);
00504    }
00505   }
00506  }
00507 
00508  /* Start running the first program in the executable table. */
00509 
00510  /* Use the ELF program header table and copy the right portions of the
00511     image to memory. This is done by prepare_process. */
00512 
00513  {
00514   struct prepare_process_return_value prepare_process_ret_val =
00515    prepare_process(executable_table[0].elf_image,
00516                    0,
00517                    executable_table[0].memory_footprint_size);
00518 
00519   if (0 == prepare_process_ret_val.first_instruction_address)
00520   {
00521    while (1)
00522    {
00523     kprints("Kernel panic! Can not start process 0!\n");
00524    }
00525   }
00526 
00527   /* Start executable program 0 as process 0. At this point, there are no
00528      processes so we can just grab entry 0 and use it. */
00529   process_table[0].parent=-1;    /* We put -1 to indicate that there is no
00530                                     parent process. */
00531   process_table[0].threads=1;
00532 
00533   /*  all processes should start with an allocated port with id zero */
00534   if (-1 == allocate_port(0,0))
00535   {
00536    while(1)
00537    {
00538     kprints("Kernel panic! Can not initialize the IPC system!\n");
00539    }
00540   }
00541 
00542   /* Set the page table address. */
00543   process_table[0].page_table_root =
00544    prepare_process_ret_val.page_table_address;
00545   cpu_private_data.page_table_root =
00546    prepare_process_ret_val.page_table_address;
00547 
00548   /* We need a thread. We just take the first one as no threads are running or
00549      have been allocated at this point. */
00550   thread_table[0].data.owner=0;  /* 0 is the index of the first process. */
00551 
00552   /* We reset all flags and enable interrupts */
00553   thread_table[0].data.registers.integer_registers.rflags=0x200;
00554 
00555   /* And set the start address. */
00556   thread_table[0].data.registers.integer_registers.rip =
00557    prepare_process_ret_val.first_instruction_address;
00558 
00559   /* Finally we set the current thread. */
00560   cpu_private_data.thread_index = 0;
00561  }
00562 
00563  /* Set up the timer hardware to generate interrupts 200 times a second. */
00564  outb(0x43, 0x36);
00565  outb(0x40, 78);
00566  outb(0x40, 23);
00567 
00568  /* Set up the keyboard controller. */
00569  
00570  /* Empty the keyboard buffer. */
00571  {
00572   register unsigned char status_byte;
00573   do
00574   {
00575    status_byte=inb(0x64);
00576    if ((status_byte&3)==1)
00577    {
00578     inb(0x60);
00579    }
00580   } while((status_byte&0x3)!=0x0);
00581  }
00582 
00583  /* Change the command byte to enable interrupts. */
00584  outb(0x64, 0x20);
00585  {
00586   register unsigned char keyboard_controller_command_byte;
00587 
00588   {
00589    register unsigned char status_byte;
00590    do
00591    {
00592     status_byte=inb(0x64);
00593    } while((status_byte&3)!=1);
00594   }
00595 
00596   keyboard_controller_command_byte=inb(0x60);
00597 
00598   /* Enable keyboard interrupts. */
00599   keyboard_controller_command_byte|=1;
00600 
00601   kprints("Keyboard controller command byte:");
00602   kprinthex(keyboard_controller_command_byte);
00603   kprints("\n");
00604 
00605   outb(0x64, 0x60);
00606   outb(0x60, keyboard_controller_command_byte);
00607 
00608   /* Wait until command is done. */
00609   {
00610    register unsigned char status_byte;
00611    do
00612    {
00613     status_byte=inb(0x64);
00614    } while((status_byte&0x2)!=0x0);
00615   }
00616  } 
00617 
00618  /* Now we set up the interrupt controller to allow timer and keyboard 
00619     interrupts. */
00620  outb(0x20, 0x11);
00621  outb(0xA0, 0x11);
00622 
00623  outb(0x21, 0x20);
00624  outb(0xA1, 0x28);
00625 
00626  outb(0x21, 1<<2);
00627  outb(0xA1, 2);
00628 
00629  outb(0x21, 1);
00630  outb(0xA1, 1);
00631 
00632  outb(0x21, 0xfc);
00633  outb(0xA1, 0xff);
00634 
00635  clear_screen();
00636 
00637  kprints("\n\n\nThe kernel has booted!\n\n\n");
00638 
00639  /* Now go back to the assembly language code and let the process run. */
00640 }

void interrupt_dispatcher ( const unsigned long  interrupt_number  ) 

This function gets called from the interrupt handler and dispatches interrupts to interrupt handlers.

Parameters:
interrupt_number The number of the interrupt vector.

Definition at line 977 of file kernel.c.

00978 {
00979  /* Select a handler based on interrupt source. */
00980  switch(interrupt_number)
00981  {
00982   case 32:
00983   {
00984    timer_interrupt_handler();
00985    break;
00986   }
00987 
00988   case 33:
00989   {
00990    keyboard_interrupt_handler();
00991    break;
00992   }
00993 
00994   case 39:
00995   {
00996    /* Spurious interrupt occurred. This could happen if we spend too long 
00997       time with interrupts disabled. */
00998    break;
00999   }
01000 
01001   default:
01002   {
01003    kprints("Unknown interrupt. Vector:");
01004    kprinthex(interrupt_number);
01005    kprints("\n");
01006    while(1)
01007    {
01008     outw(0x8a00, 0x8a00);
01009     outw(0x8a00, 0x8ae0);
01010    }
01011   }
01012  }
01013  
01014  /* Acknowledge interrupt so that new interrupts can be sent to the CPU. */
01015  if (interrupt_number < 48)
01016  {
01017   if (interrupt_number >= 40)
01018   {
01019    outb(0xa0, 0x20);
01020   }
01021   outb(0x20, 0x20);
01022  }
01023 }

void kprinthex ( const register long  value  ) 

Prints a long formatted as a hexadecimal number to the bochs console.

Parameters:
value The value to be written

Definition at line 42 of file video.c.

References outb().

Referenced by initialize(), and interrupt_dispatcher().

00043 {
00044  const static char hex_helper[16]="0123456789abcdef";
00045  register int      i;
00046 
00047  /* Print each character of the hexadecimal number. This is a very inefficient
00048     way of printing hexadecimal numbers. It is, however, very compact in terms
00049     of the number of source code lines. */
00050  for(i=15; i>=0; i--)
00051  {
00052   outb(0xe9, hex_helper[(value>>(i*4))&15]);
00053  }
00054 }

long system_time

This variable holds the current system time.

The system time is the number of clock ticks since system start. There are 200 clock ticks per second.

Definition at line 45 of file kernel.c.

Definition at line 17 of file kernel.c.

Referenced by allocate_thread(), initialize(), keyboard_interrupt_handler(), thread_queue_dequeue(), and thread_queue_enqueue().

int timer_queue_head

The index, into thread_table, of the head of the timer queue.

The timer queue is a list of threads blocked waiting for the system clock to reach a certain time. This variable is set to -1 if there are no threads in the timer queue.
